abstract.p: Two quantitative meta-analyses examined how the presence of visual channels, vocal channels, and synchronicity influences the quality of outcomes in negotiations and group decision making. A qualitative review of the literature found that the effects of communication channels vary widely and that existing theories do not sufficiently account for these contradictory findings. To parsimoniously encompass the full range of existing data, the authors created the communication orientation model, which proposes that the impact of communication channels is shaped by communicators’ orientations to cooperate or not. Two meta-analyses—conducted separately for negotiations and decision making—provide strong support for this model. Overall, the presence of communication channels (a) increased the achievement of high-quality outcomes for communicators with a neutral orientation, (b) did not affect the outcomes for communicators with a cooperative orientation, but (c) hurt communicators’ outcomes with a noncooperative orientation. Tests of cross-cultural differences in each meta-analysis further supported the model: for those with a neutral orientation, the beneficial effects of communication channels were weaker within East Asian cultures (i.e., Interdependent and therefore more predisposed towards cooperation) than within Western cultures (i.e., Independent).

body.p: In 1978, President Carter of the United States mediated the Camp David negotiations between Israel and Egypt. After 3 days of direct face-to-face negotiations offered no progression, with the views of Sadat, the Egyptian president, and Begin, the Israeli prime minister, appearing to be inherently and irrevocably incompatible, Carter made a bold choice. He decided that the only way to make progress was to restrict face-to-face contact and meet with each leader individually to draft a single negotiating document. In revising this document, offers and counteroffers were exchanged back and forth by Carter and his aides so as to avoid direct interaction between the two leaders. The removal of face-to-face contact between the two adversaries played a critical role in achieving the ground-breaking Camp David Accords (Richardson, 1998).

In contrast, when NASA fired the main engine of the Mars Climate Orbiter on September 23, 1999, to begin its orbit around the planet in an effort to understand Mars’s water history, the orbiter was lost. Because of the angle of the launch, the spacecraft came much closer to Mars than planned and beneath a level at which it could function, resulting in an overheated and disabled propulsion system. Investigations revealed that the prime reason for this failure and the consequent loss of the spacecraft was a communication error between the spacecraft team in Colorado and the mission navigation team in California: One team was working with information in English units (e.g., inches, feet, and pounds) whereas the other team was working with information in metric units (e.g., centimeters, meters, and kilograms). Investigation reports indicated that the key reason for the failure was that the two teams rarely engaged in face-to-face communication and relied almost exclusively on communication channels such as email (Mishap Investigation Board, 1999). Had the two teams engaged in direct communication using face-to-face meetings or weekly audio conferences, this critical mistake might have been detected and corrected.

These examples illustrate that face-to-face contact can hinder as well as help the ability to craft and achieve mutually satisfactory negotiation agreements and high-quality decision-making outcomes. Although the effects of communication channels have been widely studied by psychologists and communication scholars, the literature is divided regarding their impact on negotiations and group decision making. For example, evidence provides inconsistent and contradictory conclusions as to how communication channels and the potential presence of sight, sound, and communication synchronicity (the ability to provide direct feedback in real time) influence the quality of negotiation and group decision-making outcomes: Some studies find that the presence of these communication channels increases the quality of outcomes (Valley, Moag, & Bazerman, 1998), whereas other studies find no effect (Croson, 1999) or that face-to-face contact decreases the quality of outcomes (Carnevale, Pruitt, & Seilheimer, 1981). Moreover, dominant theoretical approaches underlying these findings conflict with one another, with none of them parsimoniously explaining the full range of available data.

The aim of this article is to resolve and synthesize these contradictions and offer a new model that parsimoniously explains the full range of existing findings. Toward this end, we propose the communication orientation model and then examine its validity through a series of meta-analytic tests. The communication orientation model proposes that the presence of visual, vocal, and synchronous communication channels (a) helps communicators with a neutral orientation achieve efficient and effective negotiation and group decision-making outcomes, (b) does not affect the achievement of high-quality outcomes for communicators with a cooperative orientation, but (c) hurts the outcomes of communicators with a noncooperative orientation. Our model and its empirical support in the meta-analyses provide theoretical synthesis and also offer practical guidelines to help negotiators and decision makers decide when to use versus avoid certain communication channels to achieve high-quality interaction outcomes.

sec.title: Negotiation and Group Decision-Making Outcomes
sec.p: Our central research question is whether and when the presence of sight, sound, and synchronicity helps or hinders the ability to achieve high-quality negotiation outcomes and group decision-making outcomes. Our focus in the present review is on the quality of outcomes at the dyadic or small group level. Critical to high-quality outcomes for both negotiations and group decision-making is the integration and reconciliation of different information, interests, and perspectives among negotiating partners or group members.

In negotiations, a high-quality outcome is defined in two ways. First, a high-quality outcome refers to successfully reaching an agreement when there is one or more possible agreements that make both parties better off versus declaring an impasse and walking away from the table, which would leave both parties worse off than if a deal had been reached. Second, a high-quality negotiation outcome involves reaching an agreement that expands the total amount of resources available to both parties, often referred to as joint profit. To achieve high joint profit the parties must make mutually beneficial trade-offs (Pruitt & Carnevale, 1993) or identify and optimize compatible interests (Thompson & Hrebec, 1996).

Although negotiations generally have a mixed-motive incentive structure that involves both individual and joint gain and therefore requires a balance between cooperation and competition, group decision-making tasks are generally characterized by cooperative incentive structures that encourage group members to strive for a common, high-quality, outcome (McGrath, 1984). A high-quality group decision-making outcome can be defined in three ways. First, a high-quality group decision-making outcome refers to whether decision makers select an objectively right answer. Second, in the absence of objective criteria, a high-quality group decision-making outcome is a decision that has been identified as superior by outside experts (McGrath, 1984). Third, a high-quality group decision-making outcome refers to a group’s ability to reach consensus on a judgment task when agreement among group members is superior to no agreement (McGrath, 1984).1

In the negotiation and group decision-making literatures, sharing and integrating information is considered to be a precondition for high-quality outcomes (De Dreu & Carnevale, 2003; De Dreu, Nijstad, & Van Knippenberg, 2008). For example, negotiators who achieve a better understanding of others’ interests are more likely to reach a settlement and also utilize all the available resources (Galinsky, Maddux, Gilin, & White, 2008; Swaab, Postmes, Van Beest, & Spears, 2007; Thompson, 1991; Thompson & Hastie, 1990). Similarly, when group members share and have a greater understanding of task-relevant information, they achieve more optimal decisions (Hollingshead, 1998; Liang, Moreland, & Argote, 1995; Liljenquist, Galinsky, & Kray, 2004; Stasser, Stewart, & Wittenbaum, 1995).

sec.title: The Link Among Sight, Sound, Synchronicity, and Outcome Quality: Theoretical Approaches and Empirical Inconsistencies
sec.p: Three major theoretical approaches—the richness approach, social information processing (SIP), and the social identity model of deindividuation effects (SIDE)—have attempted to provide a framework for understanding the effect of communication channels on interaction outcomes. Unfortunately, each of these approaches fails to fully account for the available data, with existing findings providing some consistent data along with failures to support their specific predictions. These inconsistencies do not lead us to claim that these theories are not valid and that communication channels do not have systematic impact on whether or not high-quality interaction outcomes are reached. Instead, we propose that these theories can be reconciled through a new theoretical lens that offers a parsimonious integration of the existing findings.

In the current review, we present the communication orientation model, which proposes that people’s orientations to cooperate or not shape the extent to which communication channels help or hurt negotiation and group decision-making outcomes by influencing the communicator’s tendency to share and integrate information or to display aggression or antagonism. On one hand, the presence of communication channels (sight, sound, and synchronicity) may increase the likelihood that communicators will develop incipient levels of trust necessary to discover and integrate information for mutual benefit. On the other hand, as the Israel–Egypt example suggests, eliminating these communication channels may increase the probability of high-quality agreements. In these cases when enmity already sits on the doorstep of impending negotiations, seeing and hearing each other may only intensify the antagonism and competitive spirit. Thus, not being able to see, hear, or directly respond to others may shroud antagonistic behaviors that can be roadblocks to information sharing and integration.

Overall, we contend that the relationship between communication channels and the quality of negotiation and group decision-making outcomes depends on people’s orientations that precede communication between them. The manifestation of these orientations via communication channels enables (or suppresses) people’s ability to develop trust and inhibit jaundiced suspicion on the road to exchanging and integrating information to achieve a high-quality decision. The overall objective of the current research is to examine whether our theoretical model is justified on empirical grounds by using meta-analytical techniques.

We first explore the specific predictions made by previous theories regarding the impact of communication channels on high-quality negotiation and group decision-making outcomes. We then present our communication orientation model as a theoretical lens for resolving the inconsistencies of the previous approaches by explaining how people’s cooperative versus noncooperative versus neutral predispositions explain why the same communication channel (e.g., the ability to see others) has different effects in different studies. Third, we present two meta-analyses to test our model in the domain of negotiations (Meta-Analysis 1) and group decision making (Meta-Analysis 2). Fourth, to test the validity of our theoretical model further, we analyze potential cross-cultural differences in the impact of communication channels on negotiation and group decision-making outcomes.

sec.title: The Richness Approach and the Positive Role of Communication Channels
sec.p: It is often assumed that communication improves when people can see, hear, or directly respond to one another in real time. For example, the added value of visual contact is acknowledged in the familiar wisdom that seeing equals believing or that a picture says more than a thousand words. Along these lines, a broad set of theories that we will call the richness approach has postulated that communication settings differ along a continuum of richness, where richness is based on the ability of communication channels to provide communication synchronicity and carry visual or vocal information exchange (Daft & Lengel, 1986). The richness approach encompasses a variety of theories including social presence theory (Short, 1974), information richness theory (Daft & Lengel, 1986), the cuelessness model (Stephenson, Ayling, & Rutter, 1976), and the reduced social cues approach (Kiesler, Siegel, & McGuire, 1984).

The key proposition of the richness approach is that the presence of sight, sound, and synchronicity makes social interactions more personal, and as a result the capacity of any a communication channel to convey multiple communication cues (i.e., sight, sound, and synchronicity) determines whether people will be able to work effectively with each other, especially when they are faced with an ambiguous task (McGrath & Hollingshead, 1993). The implication for negotiators and decision makers is that developing rapport and trust is more difficult when communication channels are limited. Thus, the richness approach argues that the ability of communication channels to carry visual channels or vocal channels or provide rapid feedback through synchronous communication facilitates rapport building and information exchange (see Figure 1).

sec.p: The richness approach proposes that more sight, more sound, and more synchronicity are better for achieving high-quality outcomes. The presence of visual channels enriches social interactions because the ability to see others personalizes the message conveyed and makes it easier to cooperate, whereas the inability to see others can make it harder to establish and maintain rapport. Eye contact, for example, can fulfill an important role in building rapport and signaling respect to the counterpart (Andersen, 2008). Empirical evidence supports the idea that presence of visual channels is a key determinant of cooperation and information integration. For example, findings reported in the negotiation literature show that negotiators are more contentious and less cooperative when they cannot see their counterpart (Turnbull, Strickland, & Shaver, 1976). Similarly, a lack of visual channels can make coordination and cooperation more difficult in group decision-making tasks (Baltes, Dickson, Sherman, Bauer, & LaGanke, 2002).

Along similar lines, the richness approach has argued that the ability to hear and speak to other is of critical importance. The level, range, and variability of voice pitch, as well as the loudness and tempo of voice, are all thought to be helpful to interpret emotions accurately (Daft & Lengel, 1986; but also see Scherer, Banse, Wallbott, & Goldbeck, 1991). This assumption implies that the absence of vocal channels makes it harder to effectively communicate. As a result, misunderstandings are more likely to occur over email than in phone conversations (Kruger, Epley, Parker, & Ng, 2005), and the inability to speak to and hear others decreases the use of cooperative tactics in negotiations (Lim, 2000; Smith, 1969).

Finally, the richness approach has argued that communication suffers when people cannot directly respond to one another in real time. The underlying reasoning is that communication synchronicity facilitates the ease with which people can socially validate each other’s opinion, which then increases the exchange of information (Dennis, Fuller, & Valacich, 2008). Asynchronous communication on the other hand, in which people are not able to provide direct feedback (e.g., in a letter or email), makes it harder to communicate spontaneously and increases the likelihood that messages are misinterpreted (Byron, 2008). Negotiation research supports this claim; negotiators are less likely to share information and integrate interests when they use asynchronous communication channels such as email instead of synchronous communication channels such as instant messaging (Loewenstein & Morris, 2011). Similarly, research in group decision-making settings has found that asynchronous communication can decrease information sharing and the quality of group decisions (Baltes et al., 2002).

Although the richness approach has received some empirical support, there is also evidence directly contradicting the approach. Mixed results have been reported for the role of visual channels, vocal channels, and synchronicity, such that their presence does not always have a positive impact on social interactions (DeSanctis & Poole, 1994; Fulk, 1993; Fulk, Schmitz, & Steinfield, 1990; McGinn & Keros, 2002; Morris, Nadler, Kurtzberg, & Thompson, 2002; Postmes, Spears, & Lea, 1998, 2002; Reicher, Spears, & Postmes, 1995; Sassenberg & Postmes, 2002; Spears, Lea, & Lee, 1990; Spears, Postmes, Lea, & Wolbert, 2002; Tanis & Postmes, 2008; Walther, 1992, 1996; Walther, Anderson, & Park, 1994). As a result, the richness approach has been heavily criticized for being incomplete.

The core of the criticism of the richness approach has been that the approach is technologically deterministic and ascribes too much influence to the presence or absence of communication channels and too little attention to the role of the social context in which communication takes place (Spears et al., 2002). This criticism defines a second set of theories that emphasize the importance of accounting for sociocontextual influences in interactions that do not involve face-to-face contact. These theories deemphasize the importance of communication channels (e.g., visual, vocal, synchronicity) and instead focus on social cues that provide insight into the idiosyncratic characteristics of the individual communicators or the nature of their relationship (Postmes et al., 1998). We briefly review the two most influential theories.

sec.title: The Social Information Processing Theory (SIP)
sec.p: SIP theory (Walther, 1992, 1994) proposes that communicators strive to develop positive and meaningful relationships and that social cues and information are indispensable for the development of such relationships. The model proposes that because computer-mediated communication does not transmit social cues at the same speed as face-to-face communication, developing meaningful relationships in the absence of visual contact, vocal contact, or synchronicity, takes more time. The absence of communication channels simply slows down the process of building social relationships. However, over time, users can adapt to the inherent limitations of computer-mediated communication and effectively develop meaningful interpersonal relations. In a meta-analysis, Walther and colleagues (1994) demonstrated that the negative effects of non face-to-face interactions on the establishment of social relationships diminish over time. Consistent with this relationship development model, negotiators and group decision makers who rely predominantly on text-based communication channels can be equally successful as face-to-face teams if they take the time to establish a positive interpersonal connection (Barsness & Tenbrunsel, 1998; McGinn & Keros, 2002). According to this theory, when people have established a relationship or are comfortable with a particular communication technology, the boost from additional communications channels (i.e., the presence of sight, sound, or synchrony) diminishes.

sec.title: The Social Identity Model of Deindividuation Effects
sec.p: SIDE proposes that the salience of social identities moderates the effects of communication channels on group processes. SIDE particularly focuses on the presence or absence of visual channels, suggesting that anonymous computer-mediated communication affects group processes such as polarization, social attraction, and conformity (Postmes et al., 1998; Reicher et al., 1995; Spears & Lea, 1994). This model, which has both cognitive and strategic components, acknowledges that the presence of communication channels—specifically visual contact—can either intensify or diminish a group process depending on existing social identities.

The cognitive component of SIDE concerns intragroup discussions and describes how the salience of social identity moderates the effects of visual contact. Specifically, it argues that conditions of anonymity (i.e., the absence of visual channels) may either lead to depersonalized perceptions of self and others and strengthen the salience of social identities that are already in place or amplify personal identity and independence in contexts in which no shared identity exists from the outset (e.g., Lea & Spears, 1991; Reicher et al., 1995; Spears et al., 1990). For example, in Spears et al. (1990), groups with a strong social identity displayed more group polarization when they could not see each other than when they could, suggesting that the impact of the group norm was most pronounced in the absence of visual contact but in the presence of a shared social identity, and least pronounced in the presence of visual channels and personal identities.

In addition to its cognitive component, SIDE also has a strategic component that describes how the absence or presence of individuating information enhances or diminishes influence in intergroup interactions (e.g., Reicher & Levine, 1994; Spears et al., 2002). Specifically, the strategic component of SIDE argues that conditions of anonymity can increase a low-power party’s strategic freedom and influence when the communication environment obscures and shrouds their lack of power (Reicher & Levine, 1994; Spears & Lea, 1994).

Consistent with SIDE, strong social identities can overcome the absence of communication channels. For example, research shows that outcome quality is not negatively affected when negotiators share a common group membership in their online conversations (Moore, Kurtzberg, Thompson, & Morris, 1999) and when members of virtual teams strongly identify with their team (Fiol, 2005; Mortensen & Hinds, 2001) or their organization (Wiesenfeld, Raghuram, & Garud, 1999).

sec.title: The Advances and Shortcomings of SIP and SIDE
sec.p: Despite their different foci, both SIP and SIDE go beyond the technological deterministic view proposed by the richness approach that communication channels have a fixed impact on communication. Both are built around the assumption that people’s behaviors in non-face-to-face interactions are driven by the interaction between technological and social cues that frame interpersonal relationships and shared social identities. Both argue that a positive connection or a shared group membership can help to overcome the difficulties that communicators face in the absence of communication channels. Thus, the theories directly contradict the richness approach by showing that the absence of visual, vocal, and synchronous communication channels does not necessarily deteriorate social interactions.

However, despite resolving certain empirical contradictions, SIP and SIDE too have left a theoretical gap by not explicitly addressing the evidence supporting the richness approach showing that the mere presence of visual channels, vocal channels, or synchronicity can increase the ability to achieve high-quality outcomes in both negotiations and group decision making. These findings have led to countercriticism from advocates of the richness approach, who still claim that this approach, at least partly, is correct (also see Kock, 2004, for a review).

Most importantly, none of the previous theories—the richness approach nor SIP or SIDE—provide a full explanation for why the presence of communication channels may sometimes have negative consequences for negotiation and group decision-making outcomes. A study by Lewis and Fry (1977), for example, demonstrated that people with a noncooperative approach to their interaction achieved higher quality negotiation outcomes when they could not see each other compared to when they could. Along similar lines, negotiations over instant messaging (where negotiators could not see or hear the other side) can sometimes yield more integrative outcomes than face-to-face negotiations (Citera, Beauregard, & Mitsuya, 2005).

Furthermore, neither SIP nor SIDE provides a comprehensive model that covers both negotiations and group decision making. It is true that SIDE does describe how the presence of visual channels can disrupt group processes and social influence when personal identities are salient, but it does not provide a systematic examination of how the mere presence of visual channels, vocal channels, and communication synchronicity can hurt the quality of group decision-making outcomes. Although SIDE is concerned with group processes such as group polarization (Spears et al., 1990) and prime-consistent behavior (Postmes, Spears, & Cihangir, 2001), whether these processes lead to objectively better or worse outcomes is unclear. Furthermore, SIDE has not systematically examined the impact of all the “communication channels”—visual, vocal, and synchronous ones—or applied its model to mixed-motive interactions such as negotiations.

Overall, no existing theory encompasses all communication channels, is applicable to both negotiations and group decision making, and can accurately predict when communication channels help, hurt, or have no impact on the quality of outcomes. Thus, we developed the communication orientation model to explain all the effects—positive effects, noneffects, and negative effects—that visual, vocal, and synchronous channels have on the quality of negotiations and group decisions.

sec.title: The Communication Orientation Model
sec.p: At the center of our communication orientation model is the proposition that the main orientation with which people approach their interaction holds the key to theoretical and empirical parsimony. In addition, the communication orientation model proposes that sharing and integrating information is a critical process by which these orientations interact with communication channels to affect negotiation and group decision-making outcomes.

sec.title: Communicator Orientation and Sharing and Integration of Information
sec.p: A key assumption of our model is that information sharing and integration is critical for effective social interactions because it increases the likelihood of comprehension, problem solving, and finding common ground by allowing people “to formulate their contributions with an awareness of what their addressee does and does not know” (Krauss & Fussell, 1990, p. 112). This strong link between information sharing and integration on one hand and outcome quality on the other that we noted earlier implies that interactions are not necessarily driven by the presence or absence of either communication channels or social cues but instead by the extent to which people share information and whether they can effectively integrate relevant information.

Information sharing and integration are strongly influenced by the orientation that people hold toward their negotiation or group discussion partners (De Dreu & Carnevale, 2003; De Dreu et al., 2008). In interdependent decision making and social settings more generally, some communicators adopt a cooperative approach whereas others have a less cooperative approach, and still others are unsure of what approach to take because of limited knowledge about their counterparts. A cooperative orientation leads people to actively seek, share, and integrate information that benefits themselves as well as others. Indeed, a cooperative orientation is typically manifested in mutually beneficial behaviors such as sharing priorities that allow negotiators to make trade-offs in negotiations or sharing expertise and unique information in group discussions (De Dreu et al., 2008). In contrast, a noncooperative orientation refers to an approach where communicators strive to maximize only their own outcomes and that typically results in withholding information that could benefit others as well as a reluctance to accept and trust information from others (Ross & Stillinger, 1991). Research suggests that communicators are more likely to establish high-quality outcomes when they adopt a cooperative approach compared to when they adopt a noncooperative approach because cooperation facilitates the sharing and integration of information (De Dreu et al., 2008).

The decision to adopt a cooperative or noncooperative orientation can be influenced by both motivational and categorization processes (see De Dreu & Carnevale, 2003, for a review). First, people’s social motives influence their behavior during the interaction (McClintock, 1972; McClintock, Messick, Campos, & Kuhlman, 1973; Messick & McClintock, 1968). Individuals often come to the bargaining table with a social value orientation geared toward cooperation or noncooperation, and these social motives influence the extent to which groups disseminate information and reach settlements, especially when both negotiators share the same orientation (De Dreu et al., 2008). Second, communication orientations are rooted in social categorization processes (Postmes, Haslam, & Swaab, 2005). When people interact with others who belong to similar social categories, they infer a similar understanding (Turner, 1991) and are more likely to exchange and integrate information and achieve higher quality interaction outcomes as a result (Haslam, 2001). The recognition of a shared social identity can result in greater information integration because it leads communicators to adopt a more cooperative orientation toward their interaction (Swaab, Postmes, & Spears, 2008). So, whether because of motivational or categorizational processes, communication orientations strongly influence the quality of interaction outcomes.

Our central, synthesizing thesis is that the type of orientation people adopt (neutral, cooperative, or noncooperative) interacts with the presence of visual channels, vocal channels, and synchronicity to determine the quality of negotiation and group decision-making outcomes. More specifically, we propose that communicator orientation moderates the relationship between communication channels on one hand and the level and ease of information exchange and integration and ultimately the quality of outcomes on the other.

sec.title: The Positive Effect of Communication Channels for Communicators With Unknown Orientations
sec.p: Although people often start their conversation with either a cooperative or noncooperative orientation, communicators are sometimes uncertain about an upcoming interaction and unsure of whether to take a cooperative or noncooperative stand. As a result, they look for information to determine what orientation to embrace. In these cases, communication channels serve a very important function: The presence of nonsemantic information such as head nods, smiles, and brief verbalizations such as “yeah” and “m-hmmm” helps to determine whether the other side is cooperative or not. In other words, the presence of paraverbal and nonverbal cues such as tone of voice, facial expression, and gesture allows communicators with unknown orientations to learn more about the other side and potentially trust them enough to share and integrate information. In these cases, the presence of communication channels help establish rapport.

Our reasoning implies that communication channels should have a positive impact on subsequent behaviors when communicators are unsure of whether to approach the interaction cooperatively or not. For instance, when they do not know their counterpart and have neither a preexisting cooperative nor noncooperative motive, the absence of communication channels can decrease the ability to develop rapport and trust and thus reduce their tendency to share and integrate information (Thompson & Nadler, 2002). This prediction is similar to the richness approach in that we expect the presence of communication channels to have positive effects. However, it also differs from this approach because we argue that communication channels facilitate information integration only when communication orientations are neither clearly cooperative nor noncooperative. By contrast, the richness approach ascribes a strong influence to communication channels regardless of prior orientation.

sec.title: The Limited or Noneffect of Communication Channels for Cooperatively Oriented Communicators
sec.p: People with cooperative communication orientations are more likely to value joint welfare, share information about priorities and preferences, and interpret others’ actions as efforts to coordinate, which, in turn, increases the quality of their interaction outcomes (for a review, see De Dreu & Carnevale, 2003). When individuals approach an interaction with a cooperative orientation, because of a shared history or shared identity, they are primed to think the best of their partners. As a result, the paucity of paraverbal and nonverbal cues present when the partners cannot see or hear each other no longer poses a threat to trust and rapport; the communication between the partners is still interpreted with the best of intentions. For example, a meta-analysis of the effects of social motivation on negotiations demonstrated that cooperatively oriented negotiators (i.e., those with high concern for their own and others’ welfare) share more information about underlying interests and priorities and achieve higher joint gains than those with noncooperative (i.e., egoistic) orientations (De Dreu, Weingart, & Kwon, 2000).

The tendency to enter an interaction with trust and rapport should facilitate the sharing of information and make cooperatively oriented communicators less dependent on the presence or absence of communication channels. In other words, the presence of visual channels, vocal channels, or communication synchronicity will not be as influential in helping communicators discover trade-off potential and unique information because their cooperative orientation is sufficient to produce trust and rapport.

Empirical research supports this claim. For example, McGinn and Keros (2002) demonstrated that people have greater difficulty developing a shared logic of exchange and coordination when they communicate through email but only when they interact with strangers and not when they interact with others with whom they have strong social ties. Similarly, online negotiations are less likely to result in an impasse when they take place between people who are interpersonally acquainted or share common group membership (Moore et al., 1999). The cooperative orientation that flows from interpersonal ties and shared identities allows people to share and discuss information and perspectives more freely, even in the absence of certain communication channels.

This prediction is consistent with SIP and SIDE in suggesting that non-face-to-face interactions can be as effective as face-to-face settings after a positive relationship has been established. At the same time, this hypothesis differs from SIP and SIDE in focusing on how a cooperative communication orientation based in strong interpersonal ties and shared social identities leads individuals to share and integrate information regardless of the presence of communication channels.

sec.title: The Negative Effect of Communication Channels for Noncooperatively Oriented Communicators
sec.p: The communication orientation model proposes that communication channels have markedly different effects when people come to the negotiation table with a noncooperative orientation. Using a noncooperative lens to define the situation, people may interpret each other’s actions as efforts to dominate and exploit, which then inspire competitive tactics to defend and protect one’s own interests (White, Tynan, Galinsky, & Thompson, 2004). Because visual channels, vocal channels, and synchronicity not only transmit factual information but also can intensify feelings, their presence has the potential to escalate (already existing) noncooperative predispositions. Thus, the presence of communication channels can create mutually reinforcing competitive tactics and intensify negative emotions that decrease the chances of disclosing accurate information about underlying interests for communicators with noncooperative orientations (Pruitt & Carnevale, 1993). Indeed, a competitive history between people decreases the likelihood of coordinated information exchange (Ross & Stillinger, 1991; Toma & Butera, 2009). Similarly, in a study examining the effects of eye engagement and the valence of verbal content, frequent eye contact intensified negative evaluations when people engaged in negative verbal exchanges (Ellsworth & Carlsmith, 1968).

Because communication channels are the window through which noncooperatively oriented people witness an opponent’s noncooperative intent or express aggressive and dominating behaviors themselves, we predict that information sharing and successful integration for communicators with noncooperative orientation are more likely to be achieved in the absence of communication channels. That is, the ability to hear, see, or directly respond to each other can intensify noncooperative intent that impedes information sharing and integration.

Consistent with this prediction, negotiators with noncooperative orientations are more likely to apply competitive tactics when they can see each other compared to when they cannot and, as a result, achieve lower joint gain (Carnevale et al., 1981; Lewis & Fry, 1977). Similarly, noncooperative negotiators were less likely to exchange a pool of offers large enough to contain a mutually profitable solution when they could see each other than when they could not (Fry, 1985). Another study found that male negotiators perceived the presence of eye contact in negotiations as more competitive and threatening than female negotiators, and, as a result, they shared more information in the absence of eye contact than in its presence. The reverse was true for women, who achieved more creative outcomes in the presence of eye contact (Swaab & Swaab, 2009). These studies suggest that communication channels intensify the already existing negative or noncooperative feelings and can fuel hostility and less information sharing.

None of the previous theories can provide a full explanation for how the presence of visual channels, vocal channels, and communication synchronicity can have a negative effect on achieving high-quality negotiation outcomes. The richness approach hypothesizes only that the presence of communication channels produces beneficial consequences for information integration. SIP focuses only on the time it takes to establish online personal relationships. And SIDE focuses predominantly on social identity as a moderator of anonymity effects and does not address objective negotiation outcomes.

The communication orientation model can account for these varied effects and offers three specific hypotheses for how communication channels interact with the orientation of communicators to produce specific effects on the quality of outcomes.

list-item.p: Hypothesis 1: For communicators with a neutral orientation (without a preexisting cooperative or noncooperative orientation), the presence of visual channels, vocal channels, or communication synchronicity increases the likelihood of high-quality outcomes.

Hypothesis 2: For communicators with a cooperative orientation, the presence of visual channels, vocal channels, or communication synchronicity does not affect the likelihood of high-quality outcomes.
Hypothesis 3: For communicators with a noncooperative orientation, the presence of visual channels, vocal channels, or communication synchronicity decreases the likelihood of high-quality outcomes.

sec.title: Cross-Cultural Differences as a Test of the Communication Orientation Model
sec.p: The communication orientation model predicts that when the communication context gives rise to cooperative orientations, the positive effects of communication channels will be lower because cooperation orientations already possess the seeds of rapport and trust that directly increase information integration. One implication of this hypothesis is that cultures that are more cooperatively disposed should have less difficulty reaching high-quality outcomes when communication channels are absent. Although behavior varies within and between cultures (Choi, Nisbett, & Norenzayan, 1999; Vandello & Cohen, 1999), we focus on the difference between Eastern and Western cultures because research has clearly differentiated them from one another (Triandis, Bontempo, Bond, Leung, & Hui, 1990), particularly in the context of interdependent decision making (Adair, Weingart, & Brett, 2007; Gelfand & Brett, 2004).

One of the most widely studied differences between Eastern and Western cultures is the extent to which individuals within each culture see the self as interconnected with others (Hofstede, 1980; Markus & Kitayama, 1991; Oyserman & Lee, 2008; Triandis, 1995). Individuals from interdependent cultures are more likely to think of themselves in the context of the larger social world, tend to define themselves in terms of their group memberships and relationships with others (Brewer & Gardner, 1996; Cousins, 1989; Cross & Madson, 1997; Markus & Kitayama, 1991), and give in-group goals priority over personal goals (Triandis, 1995). All of these tendencies lead individuals in interdependent cultures to adopt a cooperative approach to social relations—at least with in-group members.

In contrast, individuals from independent cultures tend to think of themselves as autonomous individuals separate from others, give personal goals priority over in-group goals, and approach their social world with a less cooperative approach to interdependent decision making. The bonds between members of Western cultures are looser than those of Eastern cultures suggesting that individuals cannot rely on the cooperative intent of others (Cousins, 1989; Gelfand, Nishii, & Raver, 2006; Hofstede, 1980; Markus & Kitayama, 1991). In support of this distinction, Probst, Carnevale, and Triandis (1999) found that people from Eastern cultures behave more cooperatively toward members of their cultural in-group than people from Western cultures do.

This last point suggests that these cultural effects on cooperative intent are contingent on the cultural composition of the dyad or group such that they should occur only in intracultural interactions. Indeed, Leung and Bond (1984) found that Chinese negotiators were willing to concede only if their opponent was Chinese and not when they were American. These findings suggest that intracultural interactions within an Eastern cultural context are more likely to possess the rapport and trust that facilitate the sharing and integration of information than intracultural interactions within a Western cultural context. In contrast, the development of rapport and the sharing and integration of information are quite difficult to achieve in intercultural interactions. For example, a study comparing the cultural composition of negotiators found that the quality of intercultural negotiation outcomes was lower than that of intracultural negotiations (Brett & Okumura, 1998) and that these effects were the result of the difficulties associated with understanding and integrating relevant information (Gelfand & Christakopoulou, 1999).

Because the cultural setting affects people’s communication orientations, when communicators are neutrally predisposed (e.g., nothing has tipped the balance toward either cooperation or noncooperation), their cultural background should moderate the positive impact that the absence of communication channels has on outcome quality within intracultural negotiations. Because people in Western cultures are less cooperatively predisposed, and visual channels, vocal channels, and synchronicity facilitate the exchange of information for those with a neutral orientation, they should experience greater rapport and information integration in the presence of these channels. However, because communicators in Eastern cultures are more likely to be cooperatively predisposed toward each other, they should gain less from the presence of visual channels, vocal channels, and synchronicity integrating information.2

list-item.p: Hypothesis 4: For communicators with a neutral orientation, the presence of (a) visual channels, (b) vocal channels, and (c) synchronicity increases outcome quality more for negotiations and group decisions within Western cultures than negotiations within Eastern Cultures.

sec.title: Overview of the Present Meta-Analyses
sec.p: We present two studies that use meta-analytical techniques to evaluate the validity of the richness approach, SIP, SIDE, and our communication orientation model in the context of negotiations and group decision making. We use a meta-analytic procedure because individual studies reveal mixed evidence and rely heavily on the significance of a given study finding instead of the effect size of the finding. In addition to testing the validity of the theoretical approaches, using meta-analytic procedures provides an opportunity to examine the impact of moderating variables such as our core construct—communicator orientation (neutral, cooperative, or noncooperative). In addition, we tested whether variations in findings are the result of differences in research methods used. Although all studies used laboratory studies, role-playing simulations, and tasks that were somewhat comparable, the type of manipulation of communicator orientation (individual, interpersonal, or group based), the type of sample (undergrads vs. professionals), and the time given to complete the task (restricted vs. unrestricted) differed. We tested whether these methodological differences influenced effect sizes. Finally, we tested for file-drawer bias to examine whether there is a publication bias in the literature (published vs. unpublished).

sec.title: Literature Search
sec.p: A literature search was conducted to retrieve data on the relationship between the presence of communication channels as independent variables and negotiation outcomes as a dependent variable. Articles and doctoral dissertations (until May 2010) were retrieved from theoretical reviews and integrations and through computer searches using PsycINFO and Google Scholar. Recent issues of psychology, communication, information systems, and organizational behavior journals were hand searched for additional articles. We conducted manual searches in the following journals until May 2010 for the preceding 4 years as well as relevant articles in press: Administrative Science Quarterly, Academy of Management Journal, Journal of Management, Journal of Organizational Behavior, Journal of Applied Psychology, Organizational Behavior and Human Decision Processes, Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, Journal of Experimental Social Psychology, Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin, European Journal of Social Psychology, British Journal of Social Psychology, and Small Group Research. In addition, we contacted experts in this area of research to send relevant new work that was not yet published. Finally, we examined proceedings of the Academy of Management Conference and the International Association for Conflict Management to allow for the systematic inclusion of unpublished work.

sec.title: Criteria for Inclusion
sec.p: After collection, the studies were individually examined and included if they (a) reported a test between at least one of the communication channels (the presence vs. the absence of visual channels, or vocal channels, or synchronicity) and the dependent variable of interest, (b) allowed for social interaction between the participants, and (c) provided the necessary statistical information to compute effect sizes. This ruled out studies using experimental games (e.g., prisoner’s dilemma) and preprogrammed opponents. Table 1 presents an overview of the studies included in each meta-analysis and their key attributes. As can be seen in columns VIS (visual), VOC (vocal), and SYN (synchronicity), different studies allowed us to compare the impact of the presence of these channels.

sec.p: Some studies allowed us to examine the impact of the presence of visual channels on negotiations (VIS = 1) because they compared negotiations in which these visual channels were present (e.g., face-to-face, video conference) with negotiations in which visual channels were absent (e.g., audio conference, computer chat, email; Purdy, Nye, & Balakrishnan, 2000). It was also possible to disentangle the impact of vocal channels. Some studies, for example, made it possible to examine the presence of vocal channels in negotiations (VOC = 1) because they compared negotiations in which vocal channels were present (e.g., face-to-face, audio conference, video-conference) with negotiations in which vocal channels were absent (e.g., computer chat negotiations; Suh, 1999). Other studies made it possible to analytically separate the impact of a lack of synchronicity (SYN = 1) because they compared synchronous communication (e.g., face-to-face, audio conferences, computer chats) with asynchronous communication (e.g., negotiations through the exchange of notes, voicemail, email; Loewenstein, Morris, Chakravarti, Thompson, & Kopelman, 2005). We coded communication channel comparisons by categorizing them as synchronous versus asynchronous.

Measures of negotiation outcome quality were reported in 34 articles. Because some of these were multistudy articles or allowed for multiple comparisons (e.g., synchronous vs. asynchronous and visual vs. no visual), we could extract a total of 81 effect sizes. Because different studies reported more than one outcome variable, we focused our analyses on the two important indicators of negotiation outcome quality. In negotiations that included multiple issues, negotiators could make trade-offs and expand the pie by conceding on low-priority issues in exchange for gains on high-priority issues. Thus, for multi-issue negotiations, we included a measure of joint profit, the total value both negotiators created (typically the sum of the number of points each negotiator obtained). This is an indicator of negotiation outcome quality because it reflects how much negotiators integrated information on their relative priorities to utilize the available resources fully. When negotiations revolved around a single issue that allowed for profits for both sides, we included settlement ratio as our measure of outcome quality. This is an indicator of outcome quality because reaching a deal is better than no deal (Bazerman & Caroll, 1987; Pruitt & Carnevale, 1993). Because all single-issue negotiations except one (Loewenstein & Morris, 2011) involved negotiations in which a deal was better than no deal, we dropped this specific experiment from the analyses. In the moderator analyses, we first provide the results for both outcomes in conjunction, followed by an analysis of each quality indicator separately.

Each coder coded all studies, and discrepancies were resolved through discussion. The percentage of disagreement for coding the objective study characteristics as well as the coding of moderators was close to zero. The first author independently coded all studies, and any remaining discrepancies were resolved in conference with the two coders.

sec.title: Communication orientation
sec.p: We coded the moderating impact of “orientation” using the instructions participants received prior to their negotiation. Three orientations were classified. Orientations were coded as neutral when the instruction materials did not provide any information that could foster cooperative or noncooperative intentions and explicitly invited unacquainted negotiators.

Orientations were coded as cooperative when participants were instructed to have high concern for the other negotiator’s outcome, had a positive interpersonal bond with the other side (e.g., because their negotiation was preceded by a getting-acquainted exercise or because they were negotiating with friends), shared common group membership, or anticipated future interaction with their counterpart. Research has demonstrated that these factors foster cooperative intentions among negotiators (Haslam, 2001; Moore et al., 1999; Swaab et al., 2008).

Orientations were coded as noncooperative when participants were instructed to pursue their own outcomes only (e.g., egoistic outcomes). In addition, we coded orientations as noncooperative when participants were instructed to do better than their counterpart (e.g., concern with relative gain).

A fourth and related subset constituted a group of studies that could not be coded as noncooperative or cooperative but also not as neutral because some of the participants may have had a previous experience with their counterpart. These were studies in which the impact of communication channels was examined as part of an in-class exercise but did not provide information about or control participants’ relationships. Because of the possibility that negotiators in these studies shared a history but that history could have been positive or negative, we excluded this subset from our analyses. This reduced the number of effect sizes in our analysis to a total of 72 effect sizes.

sec.title: Cultural context
sec.p: The cultural context of the negotiation was coded as (1) Eastern when the study was conducted in East Asian countries such as South Korea and Singapore and (2) Western when it was conducted in the United States or Western Europe.

sec.title: Methodological codings
sec.p: Because cooperative and noncooperative orientations were manipulated differently across studies, we also coded the manipulation of negotiator orientation into three categories. The orientation manipulation was coded as (1) “individual” when orientations were manipulated through social motive instructions. For example, some studies instructed participants to care about their own outcomes only, or also about others’ outcomes as well (Lewis & Fry, 1977). Orientation manipulation was coded as (2) “interpersonal” when the orientation manipulation involved the relationship between the two parties. For example, some studies manipulated cooperative intentions by having participants develop rapport first in a small-talk phase prior to their negotiation (Morris et al., 2002) or by informing participants that they would negotiate with the same person in the future (Purdy et al., 2000). Orientation manipulation was classified as (3) “structural” when the manipulation induced cooperation or competition through other instructions. For example, to induce noncooperation, some studies manipulated the extent to which negotiators were accountable to their constituents (Carnevale et al., 1981). For the manipulation of noncooperation specifically, we tested for differences between the two types of manipulations to (1) adopt an egoistic motive or (2) be concerned with relative gain.

We also tested whether communication orientations were embedded in the nature of the task procedure (1) or independently manipulated from communication channels (2). We further coded for the type of sample (1 = undergrads, 2 = professionals), whether or not time in the negotiation experiment was restricted (1 = restricted, 2 = unrestricted), and publication status (1 = published, 2 = unpublished). To resolve any residual disagreements, coders went back to the research report together and reached consensus on the appropriate coding.

sec.title: Computation and Analysis of Effect Sizes
sec.p: Because our primary interest involved how the presence of communication channels influenced the likelihood of high-quality negotiation outcomes, we used the group (or dyad) as the level of analysis. Because of the relatively large number of empirical studies investigating these relationships and the likely existence of variables moderating the strength of association, we used a meta-analytic approach to integrate the results (Lipsey & Wilson, 2001). In the original studies included in meta-analyses, effects of the independent variable on the dependent variables are typically reported in the form of an F or a t statistic or in the form of average treatment effects (means and standard deviations). Each of these statistics can be converted into an effect size index, which measures the magnitude of an effect—in this case, the magnitude of difference between the certain communication channels. In the case of this meta-analysis, we chose Cohen’s d coefficient as our measure of effect size. Effect sizes were weighted such that studies conducted with larger sample size carried more weight in the analyses. We coded effect sizes so that as the weighted effect size Cohen’s dw gets larger, the effect that visual contact has on the quality of the negotiated outcome gets stronger and more positive. An effect size Cohen’s dw with an absolute value of 0.20 is considered small, 0.50 is medium, and 0.80 is large. We used the unbiased effect size for our analyses (Lipsey & Wilson, 2001). As recommended by guidelines (Lipsey & Wilson, 2001), we used the more conservative random-effects model with moderators to test for the effects of moderator variables, thus decreasing the probability of Type I errors.

sec.title: Analytic overview
sec.p: To determine whether the effect sizes were consistent across the studies reviewed, we tested the homogeneity of the effect sizes. When we found heterogeneous effect sizes, we explored moderator variables that might account for differences in the size of the effects across studies. We examined categorical models to test whether negotiator orientation, culture, social context, and study characteristics are related to heterogeneity of effect sizes (Lipsey & Wilson, 2001). The logic of this test is similar to ANOVA with the between-class goodness-of-fit statistic Qb being analogous to a main effect, and the within-class goodness-of-fit statistic Qw being analogous to homogeneity within each class. We conducted comparisons when there were at least four effect sizes in each class, when Qw was significant, and when we had hypothesized a difference in effect sizes.

When negotiators had access to visual channels, vocal channels, and synchronicity, they attained higher quality outcomes (d = 0.08*, d = 0.24*, and d = 0.27*, respectively).3

sec.title: Negotiator orientation as a moderator.
sec.p: The communication orientation model predicted that the presence of visual channels, vocal channels, and communication synchronicity (a) helps negotiation outcome quality for negotiators with a neutral orientation, (b) does not affect negotiation outcome quality for negotiators with a cooperative orientation, and (c) hurts negotiation outcome quality for negotiators with a noncooperative orientation. To test the first three hypotheses, we used negotiator orientation as a moderator.

First, we examined whether communication orientation moderates the effect of the presence of all communication channels (visual, vocal, and synchronicity) combined on negotiation outcome quality. As predicted, the analysis of negotiator orientation revealed a significant between-classes effect, QB(2) = 58.30, p < .001. The mean effects for noncooperative studies (d = −0.84*) and cooperative studies (d = 0.10) differed from one another, QB(1) = 20.70, p < .001, and were both significantly smaller than neutral studies (d = 0.45*), QB(1) = 44.13, p < .001 and QB(1) = 14.29, p < .001, respectively. The type of outcome did not moderate these findings: The impact of the presence of communication channels did not differ between settlement ratios and joint profit (p = .08 for neutral studies, p = .56 for cooperative studies, no comparison possible for noncooperative studies). Thus, the overall presence of communication channels (a) increased outcome quality for negotiators with a neutral orientation, (b) did not affect outcome quality for negotiators with a cooperative orientation, and (c) decreased outcome quality for negotiators with a noncooperative orientation.

Next, we examined the hypothesis that communication orientation moderates the effect of the presence of each communication channel separately. First, we examined the moderating impact of negotiator orientation on the effect of the presence of visual channels on outcome quality. As the first column of Table 4 shows, the analysis of negotiator orientation revealed a significant between-classes effect QB(2) = 61.69, p < .001. The mean effects for noncooperative studies (d = −1.05*) and cooperative studies (d = 0.14) differed from one another, QB(1) = 24.88, p < .001, and were both significantly smaller than neutral studies (d = 0.51*), QB(1) = 44.74, p < .001 and QB(1) = 11.00, p < .001, respectively. The type of outcome did not moderate these findings: The impact of the presence of visual channels did not differ between settlement ratios and joint profit (p = .24 for neutral studies, p = .66 for cooperative studies, no comparison possible for noncooperative studies). Thus, the presence of visual channels (a) increased outcome quality for negotiators with a neutral orientation, (b) did not affect outcome quality for negotiators with a cooperative orientation, and (c) decreased outcome quality for negotiators with a noncooperative orientation (see Figure 3).

sec.p: We next examined the hypothesis that negotiator orientation moderates the effect of the absence of vocal channels on negotiation outcome quality. The analysis of negotiator orientation revealed a significant between-classes effect QB(2) = 22.81, p < .001. The mean effects for noncooperative studies (d = −0.38*) and cooperative studies (d = 0.08) differed from one another, QB(1) = 3.93, p < .05, and were both significantly smaller than neutral studies (d = 0.53*), QB(1) = 16.57, p < .001 and QB(1) = 12.95, p < .001, respectively. Again, the type of outcome did not moderate these findings: The impact of the presence of vocal channels did not differ between settlement ratios and joint profit (p = .15 for neutral studies, p = .52 for cooperative studies, no comparison possible for noncooperative studies). So the presence of vocal channels (a) increased outcome quality for negotiators with a neutral orientation, (b) did not affect outcome quality for negotiators with a cooperative orientation, and (c) decreased outcome quality for negotiators with a noncooperative orientation (see Figure 3).

Finally, we examined whether negotiator orientation moderates the effect of the absence of communication synchronicity on negotiation outcome quality. The analysis of negotiator orientation revealed a significant between-classes effect, QB(2) = 22.24, p < .001. The mean effects for noncooperative studies (d = −0.57*) and cooperative studies (d = 0.04) differed from one another, QB(1) = 3.90, p < .05, and were both significantly smaller than neutral studies (d = 0.58*), QB(1) = 18.23, p < .001 and QB(1) = 14.83, p < .001, respectively. Again, the type of outcome did not moderate these findings: The impact of the presence vocal channels did not differ between settlement ratios and joint profit (p = .93 for neutral studies, p = .98 for cooperative studies, no comparison possible for noncooperative studies). In all, the presence of communication synchronicity (a) increased outcome quality for negotiators with a neutral orientation, (b) did not affect outcome quality for negotiators with a cooperative orientation, and (c) decreased outcome quality for negotiators with a noncooperative orientation (see Figure 3).

Furthermore, the three meta-analyses of visual channels, vocal channels, and communication synchronicity revealed nonsignificant homogeneity statistics (QW) for the cooperative and neutral categories, indicating that these models are correctly specified. However, the significant QW for noncooperative studies in all three analyses suggests that this effect may be further qualified by additional moderators. We tested additional moderators of this effect in the analyses of methodological moderators.

sec.title: The impact of culture
sec.p: As an additional test of the communication orientation model, we tested the hypothesis that for negotiators with a neutral orientation, the presence of (a) visual channels, (b) vocal channels, and (c) synchronicity increases negotiation outcome quality more in Western cultures than in Eastern cultures, in which people presumably enter into negotiations with a more cooperative orientation.

As predicted and consistent with the communication orientation model, visual channels had a stronger positive impact on negotiation outcome quality in Western cultures (d = 0.64*) than in Eastern cultures (d = 0.19), QB(1) = 8.81 p < .01. The type of outcome did not moderate these effects: The impact of the presence of visual channels did not differ between settlement ratios and joint profit (p = .52 for Western culture studies).

Similar effects were found for the impact of vocal channels. That is, the presence of vocal channels positively influenced negotiation outcome quality in Western cultures (d = 0.64*) more strongly than in Eastern cultures (d = 0.24), QB(1) = 5.99, p < .05. The type of outcome did not moderate these effects: The impact of the presence of visual channels did not differ for settlement ratios and joint profit (p = .52 for Western culture studies).
There was an insufficient number of effect sizes to compare the impact of communication synchronicity in Eastern cultures.

sec.title: Methodological moderators
sec.p: Because we retrieved only two effect sizes manipulating noncooperative orientations through a concern with relative gain, we could not test for meaningful differences between different manipulations. Nevertheless, descriptive analyses indicate that the impact of noncooperative orientations was not further moderated by the type of manipulation (egoistic vs. relative gain), QB(1) = 2.64, p = .27.

To explore the impact of methodological moderators further, we tested whether the manipulation of negotiator orientation, sample type, time restriction, and publication status moderated the impact of the presence of visual channels, vocal channels, and synchronicity on negotiation outcome quality. Analyses revealed that for negotiators with neutral orientations, the presence of visual channels and vocal channels positively influenced outcome quality less strongly for undergraduate samples (d = 0.31* for visual channels and d = 0.39* for vocal channels) than for professional samples (d = 0.88* for visual channels and d = 0.80* for vocal channels), QB(1) = 12.81, p < .01 and QB(1) = 5.90, p < .05, respectively. No moderating effects were found for time restriction, publication status, or whether the manipulation of orientation was embedded in the task or independently manipulated.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Taken together, the negotiation meta-analysis strongly supports the communication orientation model by demonstrating that the presence of communication channels improved negotiation outcome quality for neutrally oriented negotiators, had no effect on outcome quality for cooperatively oriented negotiators, and decreased outcome quality for negotiators with a noncooperative orientation. These findings strongly support Hypotheses 1, 2, and 3.

We also explored whether the effects of communication channels on the outcomes for those with a neutral orientation differ across cultures. We found support for Hypothesis 4 such that the positive effects of communication channels were more pronounced in Western cultures, in which people presumably enter into negotiations with a neutral orientation, than in Eastern cultures, in which people likely enter into negotiations with a more cooperative orientation.

Although the meta-analysis provides strong support for the communication orientation model in the context of negotiations, we believe that the model is also applicable to other contexts that (a) involve social interaction and (b) have the potential to produce an objectively high- or low-quality outcome. Specifically, we propose that the communication orientation model will also apply to group decision-making contexts because these require information sharing and integration to achieve a high-quality outcome.

Importantly, negotiation and group decision-making tasks differ in their incentive structures (McGrath, 1984). Although negotiators generally face a mixed-motive incentive structure, members of group decision-making tasks generally have no other goal than to reach a common, high-quality decision. Because of their cooperative incentive structure, group decision-making tasks also serve as a more conservative testing ground for the communication orientation model. That is, the cooperative nature of group decision-making tasks should make it more difficult to find differences between cooperative and neutral negotiators because the cooperative incentive structure might give rise to more cooperative behavior overall, thereby minimizing the differences between neutrally oriented and cooperatively oriented communicators. To examine whether the communication orientation model would also be applicable to group decision-making contexts, we conducted an additional meta-analysis that tested whether communicator orientation moderated the impact of communication channels (visual, vocal, and synchronous) on the quality of group decision-making outcomes.

sec.title: Literature Search
sec.p: A similar literature search was conducted to retrieve data on the effect of communication channels on the quality of group decision-making outcomes. Articles and doctoral dissertations (until May 2010) were retrieved from theoretical reviews and integrations and through computer searches using PsycINFO and Google Scholar. Recent issues of psychology, communication, information systems, and organizational behavior journals were hand searched for additional articles. Manual searches were conducted in the same journals as in the negotiation meta-analysis until May 2010 for the preceding 4 years. We also contacted experts in this area of research to send relevant new work that was not yet published.

sec.title: Criteria for Inclusion
sec.p: The studies were individually examined and included if they (a) reported a test of the relationship between at least one of the communication channels (the presence vs. the absence of visual channels, or vocal channels, or synchronicity) and the quality of group decision-making outcomes, (b) allowed for social interaction between the participants, (c) included a task that required interdependence and information sharing between group members, (d) included a task with an optimal or correct solution, and (e) provided the statistical information needed to compute effect sizes. This included intellective and judgmental decision making tasks (McGrath, 1984) but ruled out studies using preprogrammed opponents, brainstorming tasks, and execution tasks. sec.p: The presence of communication channels in a group decision-making setting was coded in the same manner as in the negotiation meta-analysis.

Measures of decision quality were reported in 31 articles. Because some of these were multistudy articles or allowed for multiple comparisons, we could extract a total of 63 effect sizes. We focused our analyses on whether or not groups identified the correct decision (intellective task) or whether they achieved group consensus (judgmental task).

sec.title: Coding of Studies
sec.p: Table 5 provides an overview of each category in our coding scheme and a description of each moderator. Coding decisions were initially made by two coders who were trained (discussion of coding scheme, practice coding, how to deal with disagreement) prior to coding all articles. One of the coders was also involved in coding the negotiation meta-analysis. As in the negotiation meta-analysis, each coder coded all studies, and discrepancies were resolved through discussion. The percentage of disagreement for coding the study characteristics and coding moderators was close to zero. As in the first meta-analysis, the first author independently coded all studies, and any remaining discrepancies were resolved in conference with the two coders.

sec.title: Communication orientation
sec.p: We coded the moderating impact of “communication orientation” using the instructions participants received prior to their decision-making activity. Two orientations were classified.

Orientations were coded as neutral when the instruction materials did not provide any information that could foster cooperative intentions and explicitly invited unacquainted group members. In addition, we coded orientations as neutral when the study randomly assigned classmates of large undergraduate classes to ad hoc groups. As in the negotiation meta-analysis, we excluded studies that did not randomly assign classmates to ad hoc groups.

Orientations were coded as cooperative when participants had a positive bond with their fellow group members (e.g., because their decision-making group was preceded by a getting-acquainted exercise or because they were working with friends), shared a common identity, or anticipated future interaction with their counterpart.
In contrast to the negotiation meta-analysis, we did not obtain any studies that enabled us to examine the impact of noncooperative orientations.

sec.title: Cultural context
sec.p: The cultural context of the study was coded as (1) Eastern when the study was conducted in Middle East or East Asian countries such as South Korea and Singapore and as (2) Western when it was conducted in the United States or Western Europe.

sec.title: Methodological codings
sec.p: As in the negotiation meta-analysis, we coded for whether communication orientations were embedded in the task procedure (1) or independently manipulated (2), the type of sample (1 = undergraduates, 2 = professionals), and whether or not time was restricted (1 = restricted, 2 = unrestricted). Because group size is an important variable in group decision making, we also coded for the number of group members within each study. Because all the studies in our final sample except one were published, we could not test the impact of publication status.

sec.title: Computation and Analysis of Effect Sizes
sec.p: Since our primary interest was how the presence of communication channels influenced the likelihood of high-quality group decision-making outcomes, we used the group (dyad) as the level of analysis. Effect sizes were coded and analyzed in the same way as in the negotiation meta-analysis.

sec.title: Descriptive data
sec.p: Table 6 shows that the effects of the presence of visual channels, vocal channels, and communication synchronicity on decision-making outcomes are statistically significant and in the direction predicted by the richness approach. When group members have visual channels, vocal channels, and synchronicity, they attained higher quality decision-making outcomes (d = 0.39*, d = 0.46*, and d = 0.12, respectively). However, the stem-and-leaf plot for decision-making outcome quality reveals that substantial variation exists across studies in the magnitude of effects across studies (see Figure 4). Additional analyses examined whether moderating variables account for the variation in effect sizes.

sec.title: Communication orientation as a moderator
sec.p: The communication orientation model predicts that the presence of visual channels, vocal channels, and communication synchronicity affects the quality of decision-making outcomes (a) positively for group members with a neutral orientation and (b) has no effect for group members with a cooperative orientation. To test the first two hypotheses, we used orientations as a moderator (see Table 7).

sec.p: First, we examined whether communication orientation moderates the overall effect of the presence of all communication channels (visual, vocal, and synchronicity) combined on group decision outcome quality. As predicted, the mean effects for studies with a neutral orientation were significant (d = 0.43*), whereas those for cooperative studies were not (d = 0.02), QB(1) = 7.05, p < .01. The type of outcome did not moderate these findings: The presence of communication channels did not affect intellective task outcomes and judgment task outcomes differently (p = .71 for neutral studies, p = .77 for cooperative studies). Thus, the presence of communication channels (a) increased outcome quality for decision makers with a neutral orientation and (b) did not affect outcome quality for negotiators with a cooperative orientation.
Next, we examined the hypothesis that communication orientation moderates the effect of the presence of each communication channel separately.

As predicted, the mean effects for studies comparing the presence versus absence of visual channels for people with a neutral orientation were significant (d = 0.48*), whereas those for cooperative studies were not (d = 0.03), QB(1) = 7.30, p < .01. The type of outcome did not moderate these findings: The presence of visual channels had similar effects on intellective task outcomes as on judgment task outcomes (p = .43 for neutral studies, p = .75 for cooperative studies). Thus, the presence of visual channels (a) increased outcome quality for decision makers with a neutral orientation and (b) did not affect outcome quality for negotiators with a cooperative orientation (see Figure 5).
