sec.p: We next examined the hypothesis that communication orientation moderates the effect of the presence of vocal channels on outcome quality. As predicted, the mean effects for studies on groups with a neutral orientation were significant (d = 0.56*), whereas those for studies on groups with a cooperative orientation were not (d = 0.03), QB(1) = 9.24, p < .01. The type of outcome did not moderate these findings: The effects of the presence of vocal channels did not differ on intellective task outcomes and judgment task outcomes (p = .81 for neutral studies, p = .72 for cooperative studies). Thus, the presence of vocal channels (a) increased outcome quality for decision makers with a neutral orientation and (b) did not affect outcome quality for negotiators with a cooperative orientation (see Figure 5).

Finally, we examined the hypothesis that communication orientation moderates the effect of the presence of synchronicity on outcome quality. Although the mean effects for studies on groups with a neutral orientation (d = 0.17) were descriptively greater than the mean effects for studies on groups with a cooperative orientation (d = −0.01), neither one differed significantly from zero or from each other, QB(1) = 0.57, ns. The type of outcome did not moderate these findings: The presence of synchronicity had comparable effects on intellective task outcomes as on judgment task outcomes (p = .14 for neutral studies, no comparison possible for cooperative studies). Thus, the presence of synchronicity did not increase outcome quality for decision makers with a neutral orientation or for decision makers with a cooperative orientation (see Figure 5).

The pattern for the impact of visual and vocal channels completely replicates the findings from the negotiation meta-analysis. Decision making conducted with group members with a neutral orientation consistently showed that the presence of visual channels and vocal channels significantly increased outcome quality regardless of the type of group decision-making outcome. In contrast, for those groups with a cooperative orientation, there was no effect of visual or vocal channels.

sec.title: The impact of culture
sec.p: We tested the hypothesis that for group members with a neutral orientation, the presence of visual channels increases outcome quality more strongly in Western cultures than in Eastern cultures. As predicted and consistent with our communication orientation model, the presence of visual channels had a positive impact on outcome quality in Western cultures (d = 0.54*) but not in Eastern cultures (d = 0.05), QB(1) = 3.97, p < .05. The type of outcome did not moderate these effects: The absence of visual channels had a similar impact on intellective task outcomes as it had on judgment task outcomes (p = .69 for Western culture studies). There was an insufficient number of effect sizes to compare the impact of vocal channels and communication synchronicity in Eastern cultures.

The moderating effect of culture replicates the findings from the negotiation meta-analysis. Decision-making studies conducted with Western cultures found that the presence of visual channels increased outcome quality in intellective and judgment tasks. In contrast, there was no effect of visual channels for those studies conducted in Eastern cultures.

sec.title: Methodological moderators
sec.p: To explore the impact of methodological moderators, we tested whether group size, sample type, and time restriction moderated the impact of the presence of visual channels, vocal channels, and synchronicity on outcome quality for decision makers with a neutral orientation. Analyses reveal that the presence of visual channels and communication synchronicity positively influenced outcome quality more strongly as group size increased (βw = .14, z = 2.80, p < .01 and βw = .31, z = 2.44, p < .05 respectively). No other moderating effects were found.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The results from the group decision-making meta-analysis strongly support the predictions made by the communication orientation model: The positive impact of the presence of communication channels on group decision making was lower when people held a cooperative orientation compared to when they had a neutral orientation for both intellective and judgment decision tasks, supporting Hypotheses 1 and 2. Replicating the findings from the negotiation meta-analysis, we further found that culture moderated the findings for people with a neutral orientation such that the positive effects of visual channels were more pronounced in Western cultures than in Eastern cultures, supporting Hypothesis 4.

sec.title: General Discussion
sec.p: The current meta-analyses compared the communication orientation model with three existing theories to understand the impact that communication channels had on high-quality negotiation and group decision-making outcomes (richness approach, SIP, and SIDE). The communication orientation model proposed that the extent to which communicators approach an interdependent task with a cooperative versus noncooperative orientation influences how the presence or absence of communication channels affects their ability to integrate information and, as a result, to achieve high-quality outcomes.

Consistent with the richness approach, our results demonstrated that people are more likely to achieve integrative negotiation outcomes or high-quality group decision-making outcomes when their communication contains visual channels, vocal channels, or synchronicity compared to people who communicate in the absence of these channels. However, this support for the richness approach comes with a critical caveat: The presence of communication channels benefits the quality of outcomes only when people had neither a noncooperative nor a cooperative orientation prior to their interaction. This finding shows that the presence of communication channels can significantly increase outcome quality provided that people are neither strong cooperatively or noncooperative predisposition. These findings provide clear insight into when to expect support for the richness approach.

Consistent with claims made by SIP, we found that the presence of communication channels was less likely to lead to high-quality outcomes when interpersonal relationships were already developed and positive (i.e., and thus involved a cooperative orientation). However, contrary to the SIP prediction that the impact of communication channels would be weaker when people are given more time for their social interaction, we did not find that time moderated the impact of communication channels on outcome quality. This finding is somewhat surprising because negotiations and group decision-making tasks are both contexts in which time would appear to be necessary to share more information and achieve higher quality outcomes.

We also found support for the SIDE model such that the presence of communication channels did not significantly affect outcome quality when negotiators or groups had a cooperative orientation prior to their decision making. Although the SIDE model primarily focuses on the role of personal and social identities, we found that in addition to the moderating role of identity, the presence of trust, prosocial motives, and positive interpersonal bonds also mitigated the positive consequences of the presence of communication channels. Thus, the communication orientation model extends the SIDE model by acknowledging that factors beyond personal and social identity can cultivate a cooperative orientation that can bridge the difficulties people face in integrating information when they do not have access to communication channels. This finding further suggests that cooperative intentions can be sufficient to achieve high-quality interaction outcomes even without seeing, hearing, or directly responding to others.

Despite some support for the richness model, SIP, and SIDE, the communication orientation model provides a more parsimonious approach to thinking about the effects of communication channels in negotiation and group decision making. The communication orientation model provides greater explanatory power over the richness, SIP, and SIDE models because it specifies when the presence of communication channels can in fact be detrimental.4

Based on the idea that the orientation with which communicators approach an interaction is critical because it shapes the way in which people interact, we found that noncooperatively oriented negotiators are more likely to achieve high-quality negotiation outcomes when their conversation lacks visual channels, vocal channels, or synchronicity. Because noncooperative orientations can form a roadblock to agreement (White et al., 2004) and the presence of communication channels can intensify antagonism, we predicted and found that the negative impact of noncooperation could be reduced by removing visual contact, auditory cues, and communication synchronicity.

Overall, we found strong support for the communication orientation model. Ultimately, the pattern of findings from the meta-analyses rejects the central main effect assumption underlying the richness approach that more communication channels are always better or necessary for complex tasks such as negotiations and group decisions. And the communication orientation model goes beyond SIP and SIDE, which are silent on when the presence of communication channels (but not on the presence of social cues) might be debilitating for achieving high-quality outcomes. We believe our model provides a parsimonious synthesis of the literature because it successfully reconciles the contradictory research findings and predicts the precise pattern of the relationship between communication orientation (neutral, cooperative, and noncooperative) and the impact of communication channels on negotiation and group decision-making outcomes (positive, no effect, and negative).

Additional support for the communication orientation model was provided by the analyses of culture. We found that the positive impact of the presence of communication channels was greater in Western cultures than in Eastern cultures. Consistent with the claim that cooperative orientations decrease the impact of communication channels, communicators in an interdependent (Eastern) cultural context, who presumably approach the average negotiation or group decision with a more cooperative orientation, were less affected by communication channels both in negotiations and when making group decisions. For independent cultures such as those found in the West, where negotiators and decision makers likely have neutral orientations, communication channels were necessary to achieve high-quality outcomes.

For the domain of group decision making, our meta-analysis could not test our full model because no studies have manipulated noncooperative orientations. The lack of noncooperative studies in the group decision-making meta-analysis might be a result of the fact that noncooperative intentions are more common in negotiations than for group decision-making contexts and, as a result, more often studied. Nevertheless, the communication orientation model should apply to noncooperative orientations in group decision-making studies. In fact, two recent studies involving a face-to-face intellective group decision-making task by Toma and Butera (2009) revealed that group members with a noncooperative orientation were more likely to withhold unshared information and more reluctant to disconfirm their initial preferences than group members with a cooperative orientation. As a result, decision quality was lower under a noncooperative definition of the situation than under cooperative definition. Participants in these studies interacted face-to-face, and although this research did not compare the presence of different communication channels, the results are consistent with the communication orientation model in showing that noncooperative orientations can lead to negative outcomes when more communication channels are present.

Finally, the effects in the group decision-making meta-analyses tended to be stronger for vocal and visual channels than for synchronicity. The weaker findings for synchronicity suggest that the opportunity to give direct feedback is not as important for achieving high-quality group decision-making outcomes as seeing and hearing fellow group members. Future research should explore the conditions in which synchronicity is essential for people to develop the rapport necessary to share and integrate information effectively.

sec.title: Strengths and Limitations
sec.p: Our meta-analyses enabled us to reconcile the competing theoretical perspectives of the richness approach and SIP and SIDE. By focusing on the orientations that people hold prior to their conversation, we were able to explain and integrate the contradictory findings found in the literature.

A major contribution of the communication orientation model is that it provides a coherent framework for negotiation and group decision-making research, which has lacked a model that parsimoniously explains the role of communication channels. Although the dual concern model has made somewhat similar predictions by proposing a link between the effects of people’s concerns about their own and others’ outcomes on subsequent behavior (Pruitt & Carnevale, 1993), this model is restricted to negotiations and does not address the role of communication channels. By contrast, the communication orientation model addresses the specific role of communication channels and speaks to the domains of both negotiation and group decision making.

Research has consistently found that people from interdependent cultures have a more cooperative interpersonal approach with others from their own culture than people from independent cultures. Finding cultural differences in the effect of communication channels is entirely consistent with our communication orientation model. However, factors other than interdependence may also distinguish Eastern and Western cultures. Future research should explicitly measure cooperative orientations to see if they account for the between-cultures difference in the effect of communication channels on negotiation and group decision-making outcomes.

Although we focused on the differential impact of communication channels within different cultural contexts, our results do not speak to intercultural settings. Unfortunately, no studies were found that compared the presence of communication channels on intercultural decision making and negotiation directly. Because information integration might be more difficult in intercultural settings, the joint impact of communication channels and orientations might be stronger in intercultural communication than in intracultural communication. On one hand, if intercultural negotiations simply produce a neutral orientation, then communication channels may be necessary for a high-quality outcome to be achieved. On the other hand, if intercultural negotiations activate noncooperative orientations, then the absence of visual, vocal, and synchronous channels may facilitate achieving high-quality outcomes. Future research is needed to investigate these claims.

Although we included a broad range of categories to operationalize noncooperative orientations—interdependence theory by Kelley and Thibaut (1969, 1978), game-theoretic analysis by Schelling (1960), and conflict theory by Deutsch (1985)—all highlight that individualistic orientations induce different motivational, cognitive, and behavioral tendencies than competitive orientations. Despite the fact that the negotiation meta-analysis included only two competitive studies that had similar effects to individualistic studies, future research should examine the distinction between different types of noncooperative orientations and how these affect the role of communication channels on group decision and negotiation in greater detail.

A final shortcoming of the studies included in the meta-analyses is that all were time constrained. This fact is particularly important because the impact of communication channels can change over time as people’s orientations also change. Contrary to Walther’s (1992, 1994) relationship development model proposing that interactions become more cooperative over time, we did not find that the impact of communication channels decreased when interactions took more time. However, one can imagine that interactions can also become noncooperative over time, which would also change the impact of communication channels. Our model’s explanatory power requires knowing the communicator orientations at a given moment in time and then examining the immediate effects of communication channels. Future research should focus on these issues in greater detail and test whether the communication orientation model can predict the immediate effect of communication channels as orientations ebb and flow over time.

sec.title: Practical Implications
sec.p: The current research offers guidance for how negotiators and decision makers should manage communication channels. Specifically, our meta-analyses suggest both how to deal with the loss of communication channels as well as when to reduce the available channels for communications. First, our findings suggest that when people are unacquainted, using richer communication channels increase the likelihood that they will develop the rapport and trust necessary to integrate information effectively. Even when it is not possible to meet face-to-face, the meta-analyses show that having a phone or video conference to establish rapport is preferable to a text-based conversation, especially over asynchronous communication such as email. Perhaps the disastrous communication error in the Mars Climate Orbiter example could have been avoided if video or audio conferences had been used more frequently. Another method is for participants in a negotiation or group discussion to become acquainted prior to the conversation. Although it may not always possible to do this face-to-face, evidence suggests that short phone calls to engage in small talk are sufficient to establish the cooperative orientation needed to overcome the difficulties associated with text-based collaboration (Morris et al., 2002). If initial small talk is not an option, communicators can also frame the content of their communication to trigger cooperative orientations. For example, negotiators who use more collective frames of reference such as “we,” “us,” or “ours” (Swaab, Kern, Diermeier, & Medvec, 2009) or linguistically mimic their counterpart early in the negotiation (Swaab, Maddux, & Sinaceur, 2011) are treated more cooperatively, even when already immersed in an online environment.

Our results also provide advice on how to manage communication settings when negotiators come to the bargaining table with a noncooperative or hostile orientation. Consistent with the Camp David example, our findings show that when negotiators have a noncooperative orientation, they may be better off restricting their contact and face-to-face communication. This might even take the form of restricting any communication, especially early on. Indeed, a series of studies demonstrated that third parties were more effective in resolving employment disputes when they organized a private meeting with each disputant separately first (Swaab & Brett, 2011). Moreover, these initial meetings were beneficial only when the third party built trust and did not discuss the nature of the conflict. Consistent with the communication orientation model, these findings suggest that when communicators have a noncooperative approach, it may be beneficial to eliminate all communication between them and to have a third party establish a cooperative orientation toward each party separately. This finding is of particular importance because current mediation training programs dissuade mediators from having private conversations prior to joint meetings. Corroborating these findings, the meta-analysis suggests that sometimes the absence of communication channels can help negotiators overcome their noncooperative orientation that would otherwise have been a roadblock to agreement.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The results of the current meta-analyses support the validity and usefulness of the communication orientation model for understanding the impact of communication channels on negotiation and group decision making. By focusing on the extent to which communicators approach their interactions with cooperative, noncooperative, or neutral orientations, the model parsimoniously explains the full range of findings of the effect of communication channels on negotiation and group decision-making outcomes. In both negotiations and group decisions, the presence of communication channels increased the attainment of high-quality negotiation and decision-making outcomes only when neither cooperation nor noncooperation was high. However, when cooperation was the dominant orientation, communication channels neither helped nor hindered the ability to achieve high-quality outcomes. But when noncooperation dominated at the bargaining table, visual, vocal, and synchronous channels actually diminished outcome quality. The communication orientation model offers promise, at both the theoretical and practical levels, for higher quality decisions and sustained peace such as the one achieved with the historic handshake between Sadat and Begin at Camp David.
